ALLEGATION:
Foster care child has aggressive and assaultive behaviors that were not relayed to
the foster care parents.
INVESTIGATION:
On 3/21/22 it was reported to DCWL that the agency did not inform foster parents of
a child’s aggressive and assaultive behaviors before placement. The complainant
stated the child (Child A) was placed in the home for approximately one week, where
he put holes in the wall, and assaulted the foster parents and their child.
2

Complainant
On 3/21/22 a follow up phone call occurred with the complainant for additional
information. They reported there is currently an investigation regarding the foster
home, due to the foster parent’s use of restraint to stop the child from injuring
himself and others. The home is licensed with another agency but borrowed by
Samaritas for this placement. The foster parent reported to the complainant that she
was unaware of how significant Child A’s behaviors were, before accepting the
borrowed bed placement. The foster parent also reported being unaware of the
Samaritas policy that restraint is prohibited, as their licensing agency told them
restraint is allowed per licensing rules in extreme situations and when the foster
parent is properly trained. The foster parent and her husband are both trained in
safe therapeutic holds through their employment. The matter of restraint continues to
be investigated by DHHS and the licensing agency but will likely not have any
findings.
The complainant specified the behaviors exhibited by Child A included putting holes
in the wall, pulling insulation out of the wall, breaking household items, assaulting a
3-year-old child in the home, scratching, punching, and kicking the foster parents in
the face.
Chief Administrator
The Chief Administrator (CA) was informed of the allegations on 3/24/22. The CA
reported Child A was receiving Enhanced Foster Care services to help with
emotional regulation. Child A’s behaviors included yelling, throwing items, and
slamming doors. While he previously had incidents of being physically aggressive,
his behaviors had improved recently. The CA was not involved in the placement of
Child A in the borrowed foster home and could not speak to what information was
provided at placement.
Foster Care Worker
On 4/7/22 the Foster Care Worker (FCW) was interviewed by DCWL via video
conference. The FCW reported a virtual meeting was held on the morning on 3/7/22
with the licensing supervisor, both foster parents, and staff from the other agency.
The FCW explained Child A’s behaviors in the meeting. The FCW reported being
open and honest with the information shared as she wanted the foster parents to be
fully aware. This information included telling the foster parents about a behavioral
issue that morning at Child A’s temporary placement. The police were called to
assist in calming Child A. The FCW stated she shared all of Child A’s history. The
foster parents asked a lot of questions, then requested to discuss it privately before
making a decision. The meeting ended and a short time later the foster parent’s
licensing agency notified the FCW they would accept the placement. The FCW
reported she did not document the details of the meeting or what information was
provided to the foster parents. Regarding the use of therapeutic holds, the FCW was
aware of the investigation and confirmed the agency has a policy not to use any
holds. The FCW stated they did not discuss this policy in the meeting with the foster
parents as the worker thought all agencies had this policy. However, the FCW
3

believed this requirement may be located on the borrowed bed paperwork signed by
the foster parents.
Intake worker
On 4/7/22 the Intake Worker was interviewed by DCWL via video conference. The
worker reported being involved in identifying the borrowed foster home for Child A.
Several calls and emails went between the agencies, relaying information. A virtual
meeting was then scheduled for 3/7/22 to discuss the potential placement with the
foster home and their agency. During the meeting the FCW provided detailed
information about Child A’s needs, behaviors, and reason for move. The Intake
Worker specifically recalled discussing Child A’s struggles with school, behaviors at
the prior placement, and police intervention that morning. In addition, the foster
parents were informed about intensive services available to support the foster
parents. Much of this information was provided to the family by the Foster Care
Supervisor. The foster parents asked a lot of questions and ultimately agreed to
accept the placement. The foster parents asked how Child A was with younger
children, as they were concerned about their own two children in the home. The
agency reported no known issues of violence with younger kids. The worker did not
recall any discussion about the use of therapeutic holds at the foster home. The
Intake Worker reported being unsure if the information presented in the meeting had
been documented. However, the worker indicated the FCW should have completed
a placement outline for the foster parents to sign when placement occurred.
Foster Care Supervisor
On 4/8/22 the Foster Care Supervisor (Supervisor) was interviewed by DCWL via
video conference. Supervisor reported being part of the 3/7/22 meeting with the
FCW, Intake Worker, Licensing Worker, Foster Parents, and staff from the other
agency. The meeting’s purpose was to provide information to the foster parents prior
to accepting placement. Supervisor reported the foster parents were informed of
Child A’s contact with police that morning. The foster parents asked for specifics
about his behavior and were told he had been aggressive and throwing items at
people, but not attacking people directly. After the police intervened Child A was
calm. Supervisor reported his pattern of behavior was to have outbursts when off his
medication, or when feeling stress or anxiety. Therefore, this incident was likely due
to Child A being stressed about the upcoming move. Supervisor reported they
discussed Child A’s prior placements and behaviors with the foster parents. Child A
had been aggressive in other placements but never targeting any people, just
objects. Supervisor was informed that upon review of the case file it was found that a
placement outline was not completed to document what information was provided to
the foster parents. Supervisor reported she would follow up with the staff responsible
for uploading that document. A copy of the borrowed bed packet and behavior
management policy were also requested from Supervisor.
Licensing Worker
On 4/12/22 the Licensing Worker was interviewed by DCWL via video conference.
The worker reported she was not part of the meeting with the foster parents on
4

3/7/22. Nor did she participate in placement. However, she was part of the email
chain in which information was shared with the foster parents and their licensing
agency. The worker verified the information provided as reported by the FCW,
Supervisor, and Intake Worker. Additionally, the Licensing Worker agreed to provide
the requested Borrowed Bed documents.
Foster Parent
On 5/5/22 Foster Parent was interviewed by DCWL via phone. Foster Parent
recalled when Child A was placed in their home, he was very different than she
expected. Foster Parent stated she understood Samaritas shared the information
they had available, and that children’s behaviors could change or be triggered in
different situations. Foster Parent confirmed the video conference on 3/7/22 was
with Samaritas staff and her agency staff to discuss the potential placement.
Samaritas informed Foster Parent that Child A had behavioral outbursts, difficulty
expressing emotions, physical aggression, and anxiety. Foster Parent was informed
he was on medication and diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder and
Emotional Impairment. It was also explained that most of his behaviors occurred
when he was not taking his medication at a previous placement. However, the
temporary placement he was coming from stated he was consistently taking his
medication and had demonstrated no behavioral concerns. Foster Parent confirmed
she was informed during the 3/7/22 call that Child A was in “enhanced foster care”,
but she did not fully understand how significant his needs were. Foster Parent
reported she was not given a placement outline to review or sign after agreeing to
accept Child A into their home. She further reported that the worker who brought
Child A to her home did very little paperwork with her. Foster Parent did not receive
a copy of the Samaritas policies/handbook.
Licensing agency staff
The licensing agency for Foster Parent was contacted on 5/5/22 via email. The
agency’s Licensing Supervisor confirmed attendance at the 3/7/22 meeting.
Licensing Supervisor further confirmed the foster parents were informed about Child
A’s behavioral concerns, needs, and services at that meeting.
Document review
Child A’s case record was reviewed for relevant information:
 Child A was placed with a relative 10/14/20-1/15/21, removal reason was
marked “other”.
 Child A was placed in a licensed foster home from 2/1/22-3/7/22. Removal
was requested due to behavioral issues.
 A safety plan dated 2/25/22 was signed by the prior placement indicated
action steps to address Child A’s behaviors when escalated. The safety plan
did not detail specific behaviors.
 Child A was placed in the foster home from 3/7/22-3/15/22. A placement
outline (DHHS-3307) was not located in the file, nor was there other
documentation to detail what information was provided to the foster parents
prior to placement.
5

 Case contacts indicated initial placement paperwork was completed by the
foster care worker, with the foster parent, at the home on 3/7/22.
 Medication review indicated Child A was prescribed Vyvanse to assist with
emotional dysregulation.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12417 Foster parent information
(1)An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement
of a child: (e) All known emotional and psychological
factors relating to the care of the child, (f) All known
behaviors of the child, (h) Any other known information to
enable the foster parent to provide a stable, safe and
healthy environment for the foster child and foster family…
ANALYSIS: Interviews with agency staff and the foster parent confirmed
information about the child was provided during a virtual
meeting that occurred prior to placement.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12405 Change of placement
(3)The agency shall document all of the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs: (g)
Information about the child was shared with the new
placement consistent with the requirements of R400.12417
ANALYSIS: Interviews determined that information required by R400.12417
was provided verbally to the foster parents. However, the
information was not documented as required by this rule.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
ADDITIONAL FINDINGS:
INVESTIGATION:
During the initial interview on 4/7/22, the Intake Worker reported borrowed bed
paperwork was completed after the meeting on 3/7/22.
On 4/13/22 the borrowed bed documents were provided to DCWL for review:
 Borrowed Bed placement agreement was signed by the foster parents and
Intake Worker on 3/7/22 for Samaritas to borrow the home for placement of
Child A, effective 3/7/22.
6

 An “Acknowledgment of Receipt Borrowed Bed” form was signed by the
Intake Worker and the Foster Parent on 3/7/22. The form indicated the foster
parent received orientation, discipline policy and behavior management, and
the foster parent handbook.
On 5/5/22 the Foster Parent reported the meeting at her home on 3/7/22 for
borrowed bed paperwork was very brief. The Foster Parent reported signing the
Borrowed Bed agreement and “acknowledgment” form. However, the Foster Parent
stated the check boxes on the form were not marked when she signed. The check
boxes were to indicate the foster parents were given an orientation to the agencies
policies and procedures and a copy of the foster parent handbook. The Foster
Parent stated the boxes were not checked, as the documents had not been
provided, and the worker stated they would take care of that at a later date. DCWL
provided a copy of the form to the Foster Parent for verification. The Foster Parent
confirmed their signature, but again stated the boxes were not checked when she
signed the form. The Foster Parent noted the form was signed in black ink by the
Intake Worker, with the boxes also checked off in black ink. The foster parent’s
signature was in blue ink. The Foster Parent stated she would have checked off the
boxes in blue ink if she had received the items. The Foster Parent reiterated this
was not her first borrowed bed experience and she knew what documents she
should have received.
On 5/6/22 follow-up occurred with the Intake Worker for clarification about which
items were provided to the foster parents when borrowed bed paperwork was
completed. The Intake Worker reported she sent the documents to the foster home
with the staff that transported Child A to the home. The Intake Worker then signed
the forms and marked the check boxes when the forms returned to the office. The
Intake Worker stated the process was rushed due to the placement happening a day
earlier than planned. Therefore, the Intake Worker could not verify if an orientation or
copies of the policies were provided to the foster parents.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by
another agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record
containing all of the following documents:
(f) Documentation that the foster parent has received
orientation to the policies of the borrowing agency.
(g) A copy of the foster parent /agency agreement signed
by the foster parent and the borrowing agency.
7

ANALYSIS: After a review of documents, and interviews with agency staff
and the foster parent, it could not be verified that required
borrowed bed documents were provided to the foster parents.
TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE:
The agency was advised to have foster parents initial the check
boxes on borrowed bed paperwork, to indicate they received the
items outlined.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
INVESTIGATION:
During a review of the case file on 3/23/22, it was observed that a change of
placement DHHS-69 was not completed for Child A when he moved on 3/7/22.
During the 4/8/22 interview the Foster Care Supervisor was informed of the missing
document. The Supervisor confirmed she could not locate the document and it was
likely missed by the caseworker.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12405 Change of placement
(3)The agency shall document all of the following in the
child’s record before a change of placement occurs:
subsections a-j.
ANALYSIS: The agency did not complete a DHHS-69 to document the
requirements of this rule, for Child A’s replacement on 3/7/22.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
8

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status

sir_summary.summary: The investigation examined an allegation that Samaritas - West failed to inform foster parents of a child's aggressive behaviors before placement. While interviews determined the information was verbally shared in a pre-placement meeting, the agency violated licensing rules by failing to properly document that information sharing and other required placement paperwork. Specifically, violations were established for not documenting the change of placement and for failing to verify that required borrowed bed orientation documents were provided to the foster parents. The agency is clearly culpable for multiple administrative and documentation failures that compromised procedural safeguards.
